results.title: Emerald city [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Joan Long and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Emerald City is an hilarious romp which tells the tale of two couples working in the film industry and their desperate search to keep in tune with modern day pressures, without sacrificing modern day pleasures. Written by David Williamson, based on his play by the same name, the film stars John Hargreaves, Robyn Nevin and Nicole Kidman.

results.title: Embryonic development: the chick
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the development of the chick embryo, through all stages from germinal disc to hatching, employing animated diagrams and cine-micrography of the living embryo. Normal-speed and time-lapse photographic sequences, and animated diagrams, sometimes superimposed on microscopic views of the embryo, are used to clarify growth processes. (Five awards, including: Salerno; Golden Reel, USA)
results.description: This film illustrates the development of the chick embryo, through all stages from germinal disc to hatching, employing animated diagrams and cine-micrography of the living embryo. results.title: Embroidery and printed textiles
results.creator_credit: John Fitzgerald and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Filmed in a workshop situation comprised of fifteen people. David Green demonstrates and explains in an informal discussion with his participants the various techniques used in embroidery and print making. He stresses the importance of experimenting with ideas and that there is a “marriage between stitch, fabric and dye colour”. The camera gives us a close-up look at many interesting and vibrant designs.

results.title: Embracing the Future
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Historian and environmentalist Dr. Jonathon King points to an optimistic future, citing that humans are rational beings with the capacity to change and ensure a sustainable future. Phillip Toyne, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, demonstrates viable ways of reversing much of the damage done to our soil. Presenter Sue Hanckel concludes that “…we owe it to ourselves and our children to embrace the future with a vision that is life-affirming and positive.”

results.title: Embracing difference: supporting autism in Mansfield
results.creator_credit: Jessica Scott, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Mansfield, in north-eastern Victoria, is home to groundbreaking services for Autistic children and their families. With a history dating back to the 1960s, when pioneering Doctor Joan Curtis held the first Family Camps for children with Autism, Mansfield has been uniquely engaged with their Autistic community. Now boasting a world-leading set of services, ‘Embracing Difference’ explores the variety of ways Mansfield empowers people in the community with Autism to live full, satisfying and independent lives.

results.title: Emanuel Feuermann: cellist
results.creator_credit: Ernst Matray, Rudolph Polk, Walter Lowendahl and Artists Films
results.brief_description: Emanuel Feuermann, internationally known cellist, plays Dvorak’s Rondo, Opus 94, Spinning Song by Popper. He is accompanied by Theodore Saidenberg at the piano.

results.title: Ely Cathedral
results.brief_description: Commenced over 1,000 years ago, Ely Cathedral possesses many original features of special interest such as the beautiful Galilee Porch and the octagonal lantern. Detailed studies include ceiling paintings, the choir screen, High Altar and ancient stained glass windows.

results.title: Elvis: That's the way it is (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Denis Sanders, Rick Schmidlin and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Elvis: That’s the way it is is a remastered, special edition of the original. This edition includes special features such as the original theatrical trailer and the restored documentary, “Patch it up: The restoration of ‘Elvis: That’s the way it is’”. The documentary is a great introduction to the original picture, providing insights into Elvis the performer, both on stage and in rehearsal. Those who worked and performed with Elvis add an intimacy that only further draws the viewer into the world of Elvis. His masterful performance and ease with the camera makes the feature throughly entertaining for both Elvis enthusiasts and novice alike.
